ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
Gained a pair of eyes that can appreciate buildings and arts in a structural way
Drawing skills
I look up at the world around me so much more now. Not only at buildings, but at building clusterings, nature, people, everything!
I learned how to view the world through the eyes of an architect, and to draw, write, and talk about space. I became much better at drawing and at thinking through our design problems.

This course helped me develop several important knowledge, skills, and insights. In terms of knowledge, I gained a solid conceptual framework and understanding of the overarching theories that underpin architectural design. I also broadened my imagination and ability to appreciate my peers' work through analyzing different styles and precedents. 

In terms of skills, I learned various techniques for hand drawing architecture plans, elevations, and sections to visually communicate design ideas. I also improved my modeling skills through hands-on experience creating physical scale models in studio projects.

Finally, working on out-of-class exercises and semester-long assignments gave me valuable hands-on experience applying the concepts I learned. It helped connect theoretical knowledge to practical skills. Discussing my work with TAs and peers also helped me gain insights into how to improve.

Overall, this intro course laid an excellent foundation for continuing my architectural studies. I feel better equipped with both conceptual framework and practical techniques to approach design problems. The feedback and support from instructors and TAs also helped me develop self-insights.
I learned different ways to view buildings as well as gained a deeper knowledge about concepts such as form, space, and line, as well as the iddferent ways to interpret and render them.
learnt about buildings in new haven, abstract ways of looking at architecture, and more technical ways of drawing

I learned to think about space. I learned to learned to draw architectural plans, sections, and elevations, and I learned to make and photograph models. This class explored space, the built environment, and their relationships to humanity.
I learnt the basics of drawing buildings/objects from observation, which is a wonderful skill I plan on continuing with
Concepts of space, shapes, and design. Examining the works of architects around the world as well as here at Yale.
Architectural drawing, and thought
Seeing
A thorough introduction to the power of careful observation!
Learned about general themes in architecture and design, though not much concrete information. Fun to draw each week and see some improvement, built my first model.
I learned how to draw plans, sections, and elevations of buildings. I also learned how to analyze buildings through an architectural lens.

Developed understanding of different architectural elements, their history, and how to identify them in different buildings and structures. I also vastly improved my drawing skill and technique as most of the assignments are drawing related.
I came into it knowing nothing and left it still knowing almost nothing.
I learned how to draw section, elevation, and plan. I slightly expanded my previous knowledge of architectural principles.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I loved the final lamp project, and also the midterm model project.

The strengths: I think everyone I know had really positive experiences with the TFs. It's incredibly cool as a non-architecture major to be able to work with architecture students, develop their vocabulary, and talk through ideas. Alec and Trattie are similarly extremely kind and interesting people, both of whom are willing to discuss ideas or anything else with students. 
Weaknesses: It was tricky at times to understand where to start with assignmentsfor someone coming in with no background in architecture or art whatsoever, I would have liked some sections to be workshop based, or to see more precedent projects for our design assignments.

This introductory architecture course was excellent for students just starting to learn about the field. The conceptual syllabus was structured to help build an understanding of the overarching frameworks and theoretical underpinnings of architectural design. It effectively introduced key concepts and precedents, covering both classical and modern styles through detailed illustrations. The out-of-class exercises and studio assignments helped connect theory to practice. The TAs provided extremely helpful support, taking the time to ensure all students comprehended topics and giving responsive feedback on our hand-ins, which was valuable for improving. Adding more wording descriptions to the lecture slides, rather than just pictures, could help with following the progression of concepts throughout the term. Overall, the material was paced well for newcomers to grasp principles. This was a very solid foundation for green hands looking to pick up architectural design, and I learned a great deal. The TAs were instrumental in that learning through their dedicated support.

I think that a strength is the conceptual nature of the lectures and the lack of a formal test as I think that allows the students to focus on engaging with the material as opposed to just cramming it for a test.

A weakness perhaps is that the readings did not really play a large role in the course, especially because section focused so much on the students assignments. Perhaps the readings could be incorporated more into the lecture, or fewer readings could be assigned so there would actually be time to discuss them in section.

I really enjoyed the section however not everyone got equal time to show their work so I think that it would be better to have smaller sections. For example there were about 10 students in my section and 2 TAs but I think it would have made sense to have two different sections of 5 students with 1 TA each. In fact, we could have even swapped things around each time so that students would get to view different students work instead of just the same five being together.

I also think that more feedback could be given, particularly regarding grades. I think this would give students a clearer picture of where they stand during the semester and allow them to adjust accordingly. I dont think one round of mid-semester feedback and then one final grade at the end is nearly enough.

I also think perhaps there could be more engagement during lectures. A lot of the course has to do with seeing so even something as simple as presenting a picture and giving the students opportunity to say what they see could help make the class feel a bit more conversational.
strengths: lectures are short and easily digestible. weekly meeting with TAs where everyone is really encouraging of everyone else's work.

One strength of the course is that it is an introduction; you can take it with little to no experience and still enjoy it. Everyone is pushed to draw, create, and trust themselves. The TFs were very supportive of beginners.

One weakness of the course was the disconnect between lecture, assigned readings, and section. While I enjoyed the readings that I completed, there was no need to do the readings to understand lecture or to succeed in the assignments. Additionally, the lecture felt disconnected from section because it often covered abstract concepts, whereas we worked on skills in section; while the lecture was usually fascinating, it felt disjointed from our weekly assignments. The decision to take attendance at lecture encouraged more people to show up, but I question if more active listening happened or if people showed up for their 9:25-10:15am nap.

Another weakness of the course was that little time and progress checks were provided for the larger assignments (the model and the lampshade). I would have loved to receive feedback from Trattie and Alec before the lampshade assignment, maybe with the model assignment. I would have loved to have seen more work from outside of my section throughout the class. I also would have loved a more iterative process for the lampshade; I would have appreciated a review in section with their TFs one week before the final review, so that we could have time to change it after one round of feedback.
the lecture times could be improved to a later lecture time.

The lectures are a fantastic strength, Professor Purves' lecturing is comforting and warm and full of wisdom that spills over into everyday life. The sections might have been a bit more directed and purposeful.

The sketch book assignments are very effective in letting students apply and learn by themselves what had been taught in class that week. I do wish that these assignments would reference previous ones, that way I could see how my skills had grown instead of constantly trying new things that you are unfamiliar with.

This class was awesome. Lectures were great and section was awesome. I think that your section leaders do play a role in how the course goes, both in terms of grading and general enjoyment, so that is something to keep in mind.
Good course
I liked the nature of the assignments but felt as though I did not receive much quantitative feedback.

I think the strength of this course are the sections. I like how they were structured where we took the time to discuss each individuals representation of the assignment. A weakness would be the lectures. I think there isnt really room for discussion or questions during the lectures.

Strengths: Alex and Trattie are incredibly knowledgeable and give very interesting and engaging lectures. The TAs are also very involved and never hesitated to help when I asked. Weaknesses: The readings, lectures, and assignments are very loosely tied together and it was sometimes difficult to see how one element would relate to the others. There is also no concrete evaluation system and your grade is based mostly on how much effort the TAs think you put into the course, which can be frustrating.

POST GRADES. Currently grades are not posted during the semester so you have no clue how you're doing. You get one paragraph of written feedback on the midterm but no letter so you're completely in the dark. (If you don't have drawing experience, this will come back to haunt you).

A major weakness of the course was the variability in TFs. Since the class is a lecture ones primary engagement with the material occurs in section. My TFs were far less organized than other sections leading to a less engaging experience of the course. I found Trattie's lecture fascinating since they were a bit less concrete and unpredictable that Purves. I wish that the professor made more a concerted effort to connect with the students by taking questions in the last few minutes of lecture.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if they are interested in art, drawing and architecture
Definitely. If you have a creative side, or want to explore your creative side, then take this course!

YES! This is an interesting course that teaches you how to see the world, how to draw space, how to interact with the landscape. I loved it and wish I could take it again. The lecture is M/W, with a F morning section. That meant I spent Wednesdays and Thursdays drawing, and presented to a small group each Friday morning.
Absolutely, already recommended it to peers interested in architecture.

If they are interested in Architecture I would. The material is presented in an engaging interesting way and if the person doesnt do a lot of art, the assignments are a great break from writing or problem sets and really do facilitate a different way of viewing the Yale campus.
Yes! Anyone who is into art, or engineering or urban studies and wants to dip into architecture without fully comitting to harder studio classes should take this course.

I would recommend ARCH 150 to anyone interested in studying architecture, or anyone interested in drawing, crafting, or thinking visually. The TFs were lovely, and Trattie and Alec are great if you get the opportunity to talk to them.
Yes. Great practice for both the architecture student and anyone else!
Yes, if you have the chance, it is wildly different to the average yale course experience

Yes, if you are interested in art or architecture it is a very fun and rewarding class. You will mostly learn about very basic skills and aspects of architecture so if you have these skills or know the basics, this class will be very boring to you. Also, if you do not intend to go to class or put in the effort on already relatively low workload then you will get nothing out of the class and be left frustrated.
Yes, it is not too challenging, and offered the chance to work on drawing skills and understand more about architecture.
Necessary for architecture students and a good way to broaden your mind for others

I loved getting to create physical models with my hands. Although there was limited instruction on this skill, the model and lampshade-making exercises offer an eye-opening introduction to architectural logic.

Yes, I took it for fun my senior year and found the lectures to be enjoyable and different from other types of lecture courses I've taken. In section you discuss everyone's drawing assignment for that week. My TAs Silas and Tony were both WONDERFUL.
Yes especially if they are architecture majors so that they can learn some basic skills needed for the major.

I would recommend this course to another student if you are interested in architecture, drawing, or both. I came into this course with very little experience with architecture, but a passion for drawing that I have mostly ignored the past few years. This class gave me a great opportunity to not only learn about architecture, but an opportunity to reignite my passion for drawing.
If you have 0 experience in drawing, don't take this course. They say you don't need experience but if you want an A, you do.

I would recommend this course if Trattie is the primary lecturer. I times I found Purves lecture a bit dull compared to Trattie's style. If you already have an understanding of how to approach architectural space and interact with your environment you might not gain much from the course.
